data.title: Italian Words and Phrases for Travel - Bella!
data.meta_description: If you plan to travel to Italy you should learn just a handful of Italian words and phrases. Although English is common in Italy’s larger cities like Florence, Rome, Venice, and the Amalfi coast, fewer people speak English in the smaller towns and less touristy regions. You will find a little bit of Italian goes a long way to pleasing local Italians. You delight them when you attempt to speak their language and you will find they are friendly and patient as you give it your best try to speak a few Italian words or phrases.
data.text:
/

This article may contain affiliate / compensated links. For full information, please see our disclaimer.

Why You Should Learn a Few Italian Words and Phrases

If you plan to travel to Italy you should learn at least a handful of Italian words and phrases.

Although English is common in Italy’s larger cities like Florence, Rome, Venice, and the Amalfi coast, fewer people speak English in the smaller towns and less touristy regions. A little bit of Italian goes a long way to pleasing local Italians. You delight them when you attempt to speak their language and you will find they are friendly and patient as you give it your best to try to speak a few Italian words or phrases.

Not only is your effort to speak Italian appreciated by the locals, but Italian is an expressive language full of life, expression, and love. It is la bella lingua – the beautiful language!

Google Translate App

We strongly recommend you download google translate app before you head off to Italy. Even though we ourselves can speak a few simple words and phrases, google translate helped when we had to communicate in more complex situations than ordering a cappucino or gelato. We had to use google translate when Dom’s laptop was stolen in Perugia, and when Dom left his backpack on the train (with his passport in the backpack!) on our way to Alberobello and we had to talk to local police and the national train service on a 3-way call to retrieve it.

Download the apps here:

Google Translate App for Android

Google Translate App for iPhone

When speaking Italian, the emphasis is usually on the second to the last syllable. I have noted this with all caps below.

Basic Greetings

Buongiorno (bwohn-JOHR-noh) – Hello/Good morning

Buon pomeriggio (bwon po-meh-REEJ-joh) – Good afternoon

Buonosera (bwoh-nah-SEH-rah) – Good evening

Arrivederci (ahr-ree-veh-DEHR-chee) – Goodbye (formal)

Ciao (chee-AH-oh) – Hello/Goodbye (informal)

Salve (SAHL-veh) – Hello/Goodbye (informal)

Buonanotte (bwoh-nah-NOHT-teh) – Goodnight (informal)

Common Phrases

Sì (SEE) – Yes

No (NOH) – No

Per favore (pehr fah VOH reh) – Please

Grazie (grah TSEE eh) – Thank you

Prego (PREH goh) – You’re welcome

Scusa/Scusi (SKOOH zah/zee) – I’m sorry/Excuse me

(Non) capisco (kah PEE Koh) – I (don’t) understand

(Non) problema (proh BLEH mah) – (No) problem

Va bene (BEH-nay) – Good

Common Questions

Parla inglese? (pahr-lah een-gleh-zeh) – Do you speak English?

Cosa? (koh-sah) – What?

Quando? (kwahn-doh) – When?

Chi? (kee) – Who?

Dove? (doh-veh) – Where?

Perché? (pehr-keh) – Why?

Come? (koh-meh) – How?

Come si chiamo (como see key-amo) – What is your name?

Mi chiamo (Mee key-amo) – My name is…

Non parlo Italiano (Non par-low ee-talyano) – I don’t speak Italian

Un momento (oon moh-mehn-toh) – Just a moment

Oggi (oh-jee) – today

Domani (doh-mah-nee) – Tomorrow

Adesso (ah-deh-soh) – Now

Presto (preh-stoh) – Soon

Tardi (tar-dee) – Later

Piacere! (Pee-ya-chair-ay) – Pleased to meet you

La stazione (lah stah-see-oh-nay) – The train station

La stazione degli autobus (leh stah-see-oh-nay) – The bus station

Sono Americano (So-know Amer-ee-ca-know) – I’m American

Come stai? (Comay sty?) – How are you?

E gratis? (eh grah-tees) – Is it free?

E incluso? (eh een-kloo-zoh) – Is it included?

Quanto? (kwanh-toh) – How much?

Vorremno (voh-reh-noh) – We’d like…

La toilette (lah twah-leh-tay) – The toilet

Signori (seen-yoh-ree) – Men

Signore (seen-yoh-ray) – Women

Sinistra (see-nee-strah) – Left

Destra (dee-strah) – Right

E possible? (eh poh-see-bee-lay) – Is it possible?

Il conto, per favore? (eel kohn-toh pehr fah-voh-reh) – Will You Bring Us the Bill, Please?

Dove si mangia il miglior gelato? (doh-veh see mahn-jah eel meel-yohr geh-lah-toh) – Where can I get the best ice-cream?

A che ora apre/chiode (ah kay oh-rah ah-pray/kee-oo-day) – What time does this open/close?

Problems

Mi lasci in pace (mee LAH-shee in PAH-cheh) – Leave me alone

Non mi toccare! (NOHN mee toh-KAH-re!) – Don’t touch me!

Vai via! (VAH-ee VEE-ah!) – Go away!

Chiamo la polizia. (KYAH-moh lah poh-lee-TSEE-yah!) – I’ll call the police

Polizia! (poh-lee-TSEE-yah!) – Police!

Al fuoco! (ahl foo-OH-coh!) – Fire!

Fermo! Al ladro! (FEHR-moh! ahl LAH-droh!) Stop! Thief!

Ho bisogno del tuo aiuto. (oh bee-ZOH-nyoh dehl too-oh ah-YOO-toh) – I need your help.

È un’emergenza. (eh oo-neh-mehr-JEN-tsah) – It’s an emergency.

Mi sono perso/a. (mee soh-noh PEHR-soh/sah) – I’m lost.

Ho perso la mia borsa. (oh PEHR-soh lah MEE-ah BOHR-sah) – I lost my bag.

Ho perso il mio portafoglio. (oh PEHR-soh eel MEE-oh pohr-tah-FOH-lyoh) – I lost my wallet.

Sono malato/a. (SOH-noh mah-LAH-toh/tah) – I’m sick.

Mi sono ferito/a. (mee SOH-noh feh-REE-toh/tah) – I’ve been injured.

Ho bisogno di un medico. (oh bee-ZOH-nyoh dee oon meh-DEE-coh) – I need a doctor.

Posso usare il suo telefono? (POH-soh oo-ZAH-reh eel SOO-oh teh-LEH-foh-noh?) – Can I use your phone?

Directions

Come si arriva a… ? (Koh-meh see ahr-REE-vah ah…?) – How do I get to…?

…alla stazione ferroviaria? (…ahl-LAH stah-DSYOH-neh fehr-roh-VYAH-ryah?) – …to the railway station?

…alla stazione dell’autobus? (…ahl-LAH stah-DSYOH-neh dehl-LOW-toh-boos?) – …to the bus station?

…all’aeroporto? (…ahl-lah-eh-roh-POHR-toh?) – …to the airport?

…in centro? (…een CHEHN-troh) – …downtown?

…al hotel? (…ahl Oh-TEHL?) – …the hotel?

Restaurant Basics

Mancia (mahn-chah) – tip

Accettate carte di credito? (ah-chet-tah-tay kar-tay dee kreh-dee-toh) – Do you accept credit cards?

Rosso/bianco (roh-soh/bee-ahn-koh) – Red/white

Vino (vee-noh) – wine

Caffe/te (kah-feh/the) – Coffee/tea

Latte (lah-tay) – milk

Aqua minerale (ah-kway mee-neh-rah-lay) – Mineral water

Aqua del rubinetto (ah-kwah dehl roo-bee-neh-toh) – Tap water

Frutta/legumi (froo-tah/lay-goo-mee) – Fruit/vegetables

Frutta di mare (froo-tee dee mah-ray) – Seafood

Pesce (peh-shay) – Fish

Pollo (poh-loh) – Chicken

Carne (kar-nay) – Meat

Insalata (een-sah-lah-tah) – Salad

Panino (pah-nee-noh) – Sandwich

Formaggio (for-mah-joh) – Cheese

Pane (pah-nay) – Bread

Contorni (kohn-tor-nee) – Side dishes

Primo piatto (pree-moh pee-ah-toh) – First course (pasta, soup)

Secondo piatto (see-kohn-doh pee-ah-toh) – Main course (fish, meat)

Con/senza (kohn/sehnt-sah) – With/without

Da portar via (dah por-tar vee-ah) – To go

Servizio (non) incluso (sehr-veet-see-oh (nohn) eeh-kloo-zoh) – Service (not) included

Vorremmo (voh-rah-moh) – We’d like…

…prenotare (pre-noh-tah-ray) – …to reserve…

…un tavolo per due (oon-tah-voh-loh pehr doo-ay) – …a table for two

Basic Numbers

uno (OO-noh) – 1

due (DOO-eh) – 2

tre (treh) – 3

quattro (KWAH-troh) – 4

cinque (CHEEN-kweh) – 5

sei (SEH-ee) – 6

sette (SEH-teh) – 7

otto (OH-toh) – 8

nove (NOH-veh) – 9

dieci (DYEH-chee) – 10

Days Of The Week

Domenica (doh-MEH-nee-kah) – Sunday

Lunedì (loo-neh-DEE) – Monday

Martedì (mahr-teh-DEE) – Tuesday

Mercoledì (mehr-koh-leh-DEE) – Wednesday

Giovedì (joh-veh-DEE) – Thusday

Venerdì (veh-nehr-DEE) – Friday

Sabato (SAH-bah-toh) – Saturday

Oggi (OHD-jee) – Today

Ieri (YEH-ree) – Yesterday

Domani (doh-MAH-nee) – Tomorrow

Questa settimana (KWEHS-tah seht-tee-MAH-nah) – This week

La settimana scorsa (lah set-tee-MAH-nah SKOR-sah) – Last week

La prossima settimana (lah PROHS-see-mah set-tee-MAH-nah) – Next week

Months Of The Year

Gennaio (jehn-NAH-yoh) – January

Febbraio (fehb-BRAH-yoh) – February

Marzo (MAR-tso – March

Aprile (ah-PREE-leh) – April

Maggio (MAHD-joh) – May

Giugno (JOO-nyoh) – June

Luglio (LOO-lyoh) – July

Agosto (ah-GOHS-toh) – August

Settembre (seht-TEM-breh) – September

Ottobre (oht-TOH-breh) – October

Novembre (noh-VEHM-breh) – November

Dicembre (dee-CHEM-breh) – December

Basic Colors

Nero (NEH-ROH) – Black

Bianco (BYAHN-koh) – White

Grigio (GREE-joh) – Gray

Rosso (ROHS-soh) – Red

Blu (book) – Blue

Giallo (JAHL-loh) – Yellow

Verde (VEHR-deh) – Green

Arancione (ah-rahn-CHOH-neh) – Orange

Viola (VYOH-lah) – Purple

Marrone (mahr-ROH-neh) – Brown

Visit our Italy Travel page for detailed information about traveling to Italy.
